title: Earthenware bowl touched by a lizard
vignette: A gecko falls into Rivka's clay mixing bowl on the counter.

options.text: Break the bowl; earthenware cannot be purified.
Simply rinse it and continue using.

title: Cracked pot still in use
vignette: A clay pot developed a small crack but can still hold soup.

options.text: It remains susceptible to impurity while it functions.
A cracked vessel is considered broken and pure.

title: Metal tool with removable handle
vignette: A saw's wooden handle detaches for storage. Does impurity on the blade spread to the handle?

options.text: Yes; they are treated as one when attached.
No; the handle is independent and remains pure.

title: Wooden bowl that touched a corpse
vignette: A serving bowl was in the same room as a dead body.

options.text: Immerse it and it becomes pure again.
Wood absorbs impurity permanently; discard it.

title: Glass cup lined with metal
vignette: A cracked glass cup was repaired with a metal rim.

options.text: It follows glass rules and can be purified.
The metal lining makes it like metal and always susceptible.

title: Utensil made from bone
vignette: Craftsmen fashioned spoons from animal bone.

options.text: Bone utensils contract impurity like wood.
Bone is considered stone and remains pure.

title: Earthen oven repaired with plaster
vignette: An old clay oven cracked and was plastered over. Is it a new vessel?

options.text: Once repaired, it counts as new and free of prior impurity.
It retains its former status despite repairs.

title: Imported pottery from a gentile
vignette: Leah buys used clay jars from a non-Jewish neighbour.

options.text: Break them or pierce holes before use.
Immerse them like metal utensils.

title: Nested cups stuck together
vignette: After immersion, two cups dried stuck one inside the other.

options.text: They remain pure even if they touch later impurities together.
Treat each as separate; impurity on one spreads when stuck.

title: Steam carrying impurity through a kettle lid
vignette: A metal kettle sits over a corpse; only steam reaches the lid.

options.text: Impurity travels with the steam to the lid.
Steam alone does not convey impurity upward.

title: Pan handle riveted to the body
vignette: A frying pan's handle is permanently riveted. Does impurity on the handle affect the pan?

options.text: Yes, they are one vessel for all laws.
Only the pan proper matters; the handle can remain impure alone.

title: Clay jar without its lid
vignette: A storage jar lost its fitted lid. Is it still a complete vessel?

options.text: Without its lid it counts as broken and pure.
It remains susceptible since the body is whole.

title: Vessel built into the floor
vignette: A clay trough is cemented permanently into the ground.

options.text: Once fixed in place, it no longer contracts impurity.
It can still become impure like any utensil.

title: Temple utensil cracked in service
vignette: A small spoon used for incense cracked during use.

options.text: Retire it immediately as invalid.
Continue using until a replacement is ready.

title: New synthetic material vessel
vignette: A modern bowl made from a plastic-like substance raises questions.

options.text: Treat it like earthenware with limited purification.
Consider it like metal and allow immersion.
